comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mogey] our comments crossed - I was going on the light and even the direction of the flag - it could of course be an east facing shoreline on the west coast, which would match with your suggested location

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: I've just added a note on the image which confirms this as Castletownbere - there's a very distinctive building with arched windows I assume on a staircase as they are not in line with the windows on each floor of the building

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,467793,545878,7,7 There is a hotel on the old OS map in the right place too

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Wow - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mogey] is superfast today! That is the Beara Bay hotel, with Skipper's Bar.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: This looks like the hotel, on Streetview.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
The New Hotel. Castletown Berehaven 




The Hotel was built around 1842. The low row of cottages seen to the left were known as Victoria Terrace. Later it became a Coastguard Station then the Berehaven Hotel and at present is the Beara Bay Hotel.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: If you flip between the OS 25" and todays OS streetmap, that hotel was a coastguard station in 1897 when the map was surveyed.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From www.castletownbere.ie/history.html: By 1910 a new Coastguard Station was built where St. Joseph’s Hospital is now. The old Coastguard Station in the town was sold and after refurbishment it was reopened as The Berehaven Hotel.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The word HOTEL doesn't look freshly painted, so I'd say we're closer to 1920 than 1910.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Gosh you lot are quick and good!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Census 1911 Margaret Kilkeary was the Manageress of the hotel and Bartholamew O'Leary was a Billiard Marker what a Job!!!! There were 24 Rooms in the building but there were only 6 staff in residence at the time of the census, perhaps it was closed to visitors for the winter?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: From a quick scan of the Situations Vacant column in Freeman's Journal, the typical qualities required of a Billard Marker were sobriety, reliability and smartness. Often combined with other duties such as barman, waiter, or 'must make himself generally useful'. There are also establishments requiring an Assistant Billiard Marker, presumably looking for someone seeking to get his feet on the foot of the career ladder of Billiard Marker.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Nah, nahnahnah nah!  You've developed a nightmare following.  Next some of this lot will be putting up the answers before you can put up the photographs!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
You are all fantastic! I was working in our Reading Room this morning, hence the radio silence, but it's great to come back to a now known unknown location! 

In light of the childish taunting from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie], I'm adding two more "unknown location" Fergus O'Connor photos - and I'm putting ye all on a timer...  ;)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Have decided to become a Billiard Marker when I grow up! Have the sobriety (most of the time), reliability and smartness all sewn up, in addition to ability to be 'generally useful'...  :)
